intro: Thlaspidium saccatum, commonly known as the sandhill flax, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and thrives in open, sunny habitats. Its leaves are lanceolate and often have a hairy texture, while its flowers are small and white or greenish in color. Thlaspidium saccatum is known for its ecological importance as a food source for various insects and birds.
